talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable members question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Loan Council does not, within the terms of the Financial Agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, allocate or approve loan funds for specific purposes. Under the Financial Agreement the Loan Council approves overall borrowing programmes, on an annual basis, for the Commonwealth and State Governments. The States determine the use to be made of their share of the loan funds and they may, of course, apply the funds to the provision of sewerage services.

subdebate.1.para: Borrowings by semi-government and local authorities come under the control of the Loan Council through the operation to the 'Gentlemen's Agreement' entered into by the Commonwealth and State Governments. Here again the Loan Council does not normally specify, and generally does not know, how the loan funds raised by semi-government and local authorities will be spent. The precise use made of these borrowings is determined by the authority concerned or by the State Government.

The Loan Council did approve, under the Gentlemen's Agreement, a special borrowing allocation to a city council for sewerage services on one occasion but there were special circumstances surrounding this allocation, and the amount involved would not, for the reasons mentioned above, indicate the amount of loan money that has been used for sewerage services.

item.para: In most instances, sewerage services are provided by statutory authorities set up by State Governments. These authorities are responsible to the State Governments and not to the Commonwealth. The financial, administrative and policy arrangements for the provision of sewerage services are essentially State matters.

item.para: The Commonwealth Statistician is carrying out the investigation required in order to obtain later information in relation to sewerage services in each State capital, but he is not, as yet, in a position to provide an answer. When he is, I shall arrange lo supply the answer in writing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

item.para: Do existing contracts for the transport of migrants from Britain and Northern Europe expire on 30th June 1970.
If so, what decisions have been taken by the Government on migrant transport for the period commencing 1st July 1970.
Do these decisions vary the existing arrangements and, if so, why has the Government decided on such changes?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) It has been the practice over a number of years to enter into a contract with a shipping company for the basic foreseen requirements of migrant shipping berths over a 3 year period from Britain and Northern Europe. In addition to the berths under contract other carriers have provided non-contract berths as required by my Department. These berths were taken at the price established for the contract berths.

subdebate.1.para: The existing contract expires on 30th June, and on 19th August last all six passenger shipping lines operating to Australia were invited to make offers slating the number of berths available and the price for a 3 or 5 year period commencing on 1st July 1970.

Three shipping companies offered berths on a contract basis. The remainder though unwilling to contract indicated their interest in providing berths at the price which would be established by any contract given by the Commonwealth.

After a careful assessment of the contract offers the Government decided to accept the offer from Chandris Lines and to contract wilh that company for its basic requirements of sea berths over the 3 years as from 1st July.

The contract will provide 36,000 firm berths and up to a total of 15,000 berths to be taken at the option of the Commonwealth. For the remainder of the assisted passage programme from Britain and Northern Europe sea berths will be taken from non-contract carriers and air seats from Qantas.

item.para: The new arrangements involve a change of contractor and an increased use of air movement for migrants.

subdebate.1.para: The decision does not reflect in any way upon the Sitmar Line - the former contractor. The service provided by this company has been maintained at a high level over the many years that the company was engaged in migrant transport.

Chandris Lines has been carrying migrants for many years. The ships of its existing fleet which will be used for migrant traffic have always provided a completely satisfactory service in the past. To these will be added a newly acquired vessel which will undergo a re-fit. The accommodation provided on this ship will be subject to inspection by my Department before it is used for migrant transport.
In changing from the existingcontractor, Sitmar Line, the Government was influenced by the significantly lower price per berth quoted by the new contractor and by Qantas.

Also the smaller total of berths offered by the new contractor met more readily the Government's growing recognition of the increasing air component need in migrant transport, while still leaving the choice of sea transport for those prefering it.

The new sea transport contract will be for basic requirements only. There will be a much larger proportion of air transport used than previously and by the end of the three-year period of the contract it is expected that approximately 75% of assisted migrants will travel by air from Britain and Northern Europe.

Already the movement of assisted migrants by air has grown to half the total assisted programme. This represents an exercise of the migrant's own preference for this form of travel and is consistent with world trends in general passenger movement by air. The Government's calculated use of more air transport now anticipates the requirements of the future and will make the transition more orderly.

The decision to increase the air component followed some months of careful analysis and examination of its implications and consultation with senior officers abroad. The Government and its advisers are satisfied that the decision will not adversely affect migrant programmes.
This is underlined by the fact that programmes from areas where migrants are now moved totally by air have not suffered in any way because of this.

There is advantage also to the migrant in the quicker voyage and the earlier entry into gainful employment in Australia. Thirty hours only in travelling time from Europe helps to diminish any initial sense of isolation from his homeland felt by the new settler.

The Government's decision for the next three years does not necessarily pre-suppose a move into total air transport in the future. But when transport contracts need to be renewed in 1973 the Government, on the basis of experience of the next three years, will naturally assess the desirability of such a move.
In summary, therefore, the new arrangements determined by the Government will involve:

item.label: (i)
item.para: A change of sea contractor.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The increased use of air transport by Qantas but no actual commitment to total air movement in the future.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: The preservation of a choice of sea transport for those who prefer it.

item.label: (iv)
item.para: A considerable saving in transport costs.

item.label: (v)
item.para: No adverse effect upon the total immigration programme.

subdebate.1.para: As well as being less expensive air transport importantly will be provided from our own national resources (Qantas) although for limited periods, as in the past, some sub-chartering will be necessary. Thus there are national benefits which go beyond the immediate question of migrant transport and a necessary adjustment to developing changes in world travel.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

quote.para: Will he make available full details of arrangements made with shipping and airline companies for the transport of migrants, including (a) the numbers to be carried by (i) sea and (ii) air, (b) the names of the companies involved in each case and (c) the period of the contracts.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honour able member's question is as follows:

quote.para: In response to the Government's invitation of 19th August last to all passenger shipping lines operating from Europe to Australia, three companies offered to carry migrants by sea on a contract basis. Following a careful assessment of these offers the Government decided to accept the offer from Chandris Lines and to contract with that company for its basic requirements.

It is expected that the contract with Chandris Lines will provide, over a three year period commencing 1st July 1970, 36,000 firm berths and up to 15,000 berths to be taken at the option of the Commonwealth for the carriage of migrants from Britain and Northern Europe. Within this three year period additional sea berths will be taken when offered by carriers other than the contract carrier and when required by the Government.
The remainder of the assisted passage programme from the northern area will be carried by Qantas and/or its associates.

It is expected that air transport will be used for any increased numbers in programmes in subsequent years and will, in addition, progressively take over movement from Britain and Northern Europe from non-contract shipping after 1970-71.
It is proposed to enter into a contract also with Qantas for the air movement of migrants from all areas including Britain and Northern Europe.

It is envisaged at this stage that approximately 72,000 air movements by Qantas will be involved in 1970-71 but this figure is subject to budget approval by Parliament covering the programme for that year.
The size of immigration programmes in subsequent years will be governed by policy determinations and budget approval.

Assisted passage movements from areas other than Britain and Northern Europe are currently arranged either through the Inter-Governmental Committee for European Migration or on an ad hoc' basis directly with carriers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

item.para: Is it the intention of his Department in future to transport migrants exclusively by air.
If so, when is it anticipated that this change will take effect, and what are the reasons for the change.
What will be the estimated saving in transport costs for the period of the contract if all migrants travel by air.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honour able member's question is as follows:

item.para: There will be a significant increase in the number of migrants moved by air during the years 1970-73. This does not mean, however, that the Government has taken a decision lo use air exclusively for the transport of migrants either during this period or in later years.

subdebate.1.para: Thirty-six thousand firm sea berths and up to 15,000 sea berths to be taken at the option of the Commonwealth will be provided by contract from 1970 to 1973. This will give a choice of sea travel for those who prefer it.

From the beginning of 1970-71 for movements from Britain and Northern Europe there will be a change in emphasis from approximately equal sharing between sea and air to about a 3:1 ratio in favour of air. After 1970-71 air transport will take up any increases in the annual assisted migration programme and will progressively absorb sea movements not covered by contracts from those sources.

item.para: When transport contracts arc being renegotiated early in 1973 the question of total movement by air will be considered by the Government in the light of experience. Such an assessment cannot at this stage be said to presuppose exclusive air movement as from 1973.
The question of estimated saving in transport costs if all migrants travel by air is therefore hypothetical.
